title: Phishing
summary: Deceptive emails and websites that impersonate trusted organizations to steal credentials and personal information.
description:
Phishing is one of the most prevalent cyberattacks in use today. Attackers craft convincing emails, text messages, or fake websites that appear to come from legitimate organizations ‚Äî your bank, a delivery company, your employer, or a government agency. The goal is to trick you into revealing sensitive information such as passwords, credit card numbers, or Social Security numbers, or to get you to download malicious software.

Modern phishing attacks are highly sophisticated. Spear phishing targets specific individuals using personal information gathered from social media. Whaling attacks target senior executives. Vishing uses phone calls. Smishing uses SMS text messages. Pharming redirects DNS queries so that even correctly typed URLs lead to fake sites.

Phishing attacks succeed because they exploit human psychology ‚Äî creating urgency, fear, authority, or curiosity to override careful thinking. A convincing phishing email can be nearly indistinguishable from a legitimate one.
warningSigns: Sender email domain does not exactly match the real organization (e.g., 'paypa1.com' vs 'paypal.com')
Urgent or threatening language demanding immediate action
Generic greetings like 'Dear Customer' instead of your name
Links that show a different URL when you hover over them
Requests for login credentials, passwords, or payment information via email
Unexpected attachments, especially .exe, .zip, or Office files with macros
Poor grammar and spelling (though modern AI-generated phishing may be grammatically perfect)
Reply-To address differs from the From address
preventionTips: Always verify the sender's full email address, not just the display name
Hover over links before clicking to see the real destination URL
Navigate to websites by typing the URL directly rather than clicking email links
Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) on all important accounts
Use a password manager ‚Äî it will not autofill credentials on fake sites
Report suspicious emails to your IT team or email provider
Keep your browser and operating system updated to patch known exploits
Use email security tools that flag suspicious messages

title: Malware
summary: Malicious software including viruses, trojans, and spyware designed to damage systems or steal data.
description:
Malware ‚Äî short for malicious software ‚Äî is any program or code created to harm, disrupt, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems. It encompasses a broad family of threats including viruses (self-replicating code that attaches to legitimate files), worms (self-propagating across networks), trojans (disguised as legitimate software), spyware (secretly monitors activity), adware (injects unwanted advertisements), rootkits (hides its presence deep in the system), and keyloggers (records every keystroke).

Malware typically enters systems through phishing email attachments, malicious website downloads, infected USB drives, compromised software installers, or exploit kits that target unpatched vulnerabilities. Once installed, it may lie dormant to avoid detection, exfiltrate data to remote command-and-control servers, enlist the device in a botnet for coordinated attacks, or hold the system hostage for ransom.

The consequences range from annoying (browser redirects, pop-up ads) to catastrophic (complete data loss, financial theft, industrial sabotage). Modern malware is professionally developed, regularly updated to evade antivirus detection, and often sold as Malware-as-a-Service on dark web markets.
warningSigns: Computer is noticeably slower than usual
Unexpected pop-up advertisements appearing on the desktop or in browsers
Browser homepage or search engine changed without your permission
New programs or toolbars you did not install
Antivirus software has been disabled and cannot be re-enabled
Files are missing, renamed, or encrypted
High network activity when you are not actively browsing
Computer crashes frequently or behaves erratically
preventionTips: Keep your operating system and all software up to date with security patches
Install reputable antivirus/endpoint protection software and keep it updated
Only download software from official, trusted sources
Do not open email attachments from unknown senders
Use a standard (non-administrator) account for daily computing
Enable your operating system's built-in firewall
Back up important data regularly to an offline location
Be cautious with USB drives ‚Äî scan them before opening any files

title: Ransomware
summary: A type of malware that encrypts your files and demands payment in cryptocurrency to restore access.
description:
Ransomware is a category of malware that encrypts the victim's files or locks them out of their system, then demands a ransom payment ‚Äî typically in cryptocurrency ‚Äî for the decryption key. It has become one of the most financially devastating forms of cybercrime, costing organizations billions of dollars annually and targeting everyone from individuals to hospitals, schools, government agencies, and Fortune 500 companies.

Modern ransomware attacks often follow a double-extortion model: attackers not only encrypt your data but also exfiltrate it first, threatening to publish sensitive information publicly if the ransom is not paid. Triple-extortion adds DDoS attacks against the victim as additional pressure.

Ransomware commonly spreads through phishing emails with malicious attachments, vulnerable remote desktop protocol (RDP) connections, unpatched software vulnerabilities, and compromised credentials purchased on dark web markets. After gaining entry, attackers may spend weeks or months quietly moving through the network before triggering encryption ‚Äî ensuring maximum damage and leverage.

Paying the ransom does not guarantee data recovery; a significant percentage of victims who pay never receive working decryption keys, and payment funds further criminal operations.
warningSigns: Files suddenly cannot be opened and appear renamed with unfamiliar extensions
A ransom demand note appears on the screen or desktop
Unusually high disk and CPU activity
Security software has been disabled
Network shares become inaccessible
System performance degrades dramatically over a short period
Backup files or shadow copies have been deleted
Colleagues report the same issues simultaneously ‚Äî indicating network spread
preventionTips: Maintain regular offline backups following the 3-2-1 rule: 3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite
Keep all software, especially operating systems and RDP, patched and updated
Disable Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) if not needed; use a VPN if required
Implement network segmentation to limit lateral movement
Use strong, unique passwords and enable MFA on all accounts
Restrict user privileges ‚Äî employees should only access what they need
Deploy email filtering and anti-phishing tools
Create and regularly test an incident response plan

title: Social Engineering
summary: Psychological manipulation techniques that exploit human trust and behavior to bypass security controls.
description:
Social engineering is the art of manipulating people into performing actions or divulging confidential information. Unlike technical attacks that exploit software vulnerabilities, social engineering exploits human psychology ‚Äî targeting emotions like trust, fear, curiosity, urgency, authority, and reciprocity.

Attackers research their targets extensively using publicly available information from LinkedIn, company websites, and social media to craft convincing scenarios. Common techniques include pretexting (creating a fabricated scenario to extract information), baiting (using curiosity or greed as a lure), quid pro quo (offering something in exchange for information), tailgating (physically following authorized personnel into secure areas), and vishing (voice phishing over phone calls).

Social engineering is effective because even technically sophisticated individuals are susceptible to psychological manipulation. Security is only as strong as its human components. Attackers understand that it is often easier to trick a person than to break encryption or exploit unpatched software.

Businesses are frequently targeted through Business Email Compromise (BEC), where attackers impersonate executives to authorize fraudulent wire transfers. These attacks alone have caused billions of dollars in losses globally.
warningSigns: Unexpected requests for sensitive information, even from seemingly known contacts
High-pressure scenarios creating urgency or fear (act now or face consequences)
Requests to bypass normal security procedures 'just this once'
Someone claims authority they cannot easily verify
An offer that seems unusually generous or too good to be true
Unexpected phone calls from 'IT support' or 'Microsoft' claiming your system has issues
A stranger trying to follow you into a secure area
Email from a 'colleague' requesting unusual information or immediate payments
preventionTips: Verify identity independently ‚Äî call back on a known number, not one provided in the contact
Establish clear protocols for sensitive requests like wire transfers that require multiple approvals
Train all staff regularly on social engineering tactics and red flags
Create a culture where it is safe to question unusual requests without feeling rude
Never provide credentials, even to IT staff ‚Äî they should not need your password
Be skeptical of urgency ‚Äî attackers rush you to prevent careful thinking
Implement strict visitor and physical access controls
Report suspicious contacts to your security team immediately

title: Man-in-the-Middle
summary: Attacks where a third party secretly intercepts and potentially alters communication between two parties.
description:
A Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attack occurs when an attacker secretly intercepts and relays communication between two parties who believe they are communicating directly with each other. The attacker can passively eavesdrop on the conversation, actively inject or modify data, impersonate one or both parties, and strip encryption from connections.

Common MitM attack vectors include ARP spoofing on local networks (the attacker poisons ARP tables to route traffic through their machine), rogue Wi-Fi access points (creating fake 'free Wi-Fi' hotspots in public places), DNS spoofing (redirecting domain name lookups to attacker-controlled IP addresses), SSL stripping (downgrading HTTPS connections to HTTP), and BGP hijacking (large-scale internet routing manipulation).

Public Wi-Fi networks are particularly dangerous. A rogue hotspot can be set up trivially with a smartphone, and all unencrypted traffic passing through it is fully visible to the operator. Even corporate VPNs are sometimes vulnerable if the VPN endpoint itself is compromised.

The rise of HTTPS has significantly mitigated browser-based MitM attacks by encrypting traffic and authenticating server identity via certificates, but misconfigured systems, outdated protocols, and user acceptance of certificate warnings continue to create opportunities for attackers.
warningSigns: Unexpected SSL/TLS certificate warnings in your browser
Certificate authority is unknown or untrusted
Websites loading over HTTP when they normally use HTTPS
Being asked to accept a new certificate for a site you visit regularly
Unusually slow network performance suggesting traffic is being routed through extra hops
Unexpected disconnections or session terminations
Two-factor authentication codes being requested multiple times
Accounts showing logins from unfamiliar locations while you are active
preventionTips: Always use HTTPS ‚Äî check for the padlock and 'https://' before entering sensitive data
Avoid using public Wi-Fi for sensitive activities ‚Äî use a reputable VPN if necessary
Never ignore SSL certificate warnings ‚Äî they may indicate an active attack
Enable HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) on websites you operate
Use encrypted DNS (DNS over HTTPS or DNS over TLS)
Keep your device's trusted certificate store up to date
Use end-to-end encrypted messaging apps for sensitive communications
Enable certificate pinning in mobile apps where possible

title: Password Attacks
summary: Techniques used to crack or steal passwords, including brute force, dictionary attacks, and credential stuffing.
description:
Password attacks encompass a range of techniques attackers use to gain unauthorized access to accounts by obtaining or guessing credentials. They are among the most common initial access methods because passwords remain the primary authentication mechanism for most systems.

Brute force attacks try every possible combination of characters until the correct password is found. Dictionary attacks use wordlists of common passwords and their variations. Credential stuffing takes username/password pairs leaked from one breach and automatically tests them across hundreds of other services ‚Äî highly effective because people reuse passwords. Password spraying tries a small number of common passwords against many accounts to avoid lockouts. Keyloggers capture passwords as users type them. Shoulder surfing is simply watching someone type their password in public.

Once attackers obtain credentials, they may sell them on dark web marketplaces, use them to access additional accounts through password reuse, or leverage them for more sophisticated attacks on corporate networks. Billions of credentials from past breaches are freely available online, making credential stuffing trivially easy to execute at scale.

The Have I Been Pwned service (haveibeenpwned.com) maintains a database of over 12 billion compromised passwords from known breaches and provides a privacy-respecting API to check if a password has been exposed.
warningSigns: Receiving unexpected password reset emails you did not request
Account login alerts from unfamiliar locations or devices
Being locked out of your account after too many failed login attempts
Unusual activity in your accounts ‚Äî messages sent, settings changed
Other accounts using the same password showing suspicious activity
Security questions have been changed without your knowledge
Unauthorized purchases or transactions
Friends or contacts receiving messages you did not send
preventionTips: Use a unique, strong password for every account ‚Äî never reuse passwords
Use a reputable password manager to generate and store complex passwords
Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) on all accounts that support it
Use long passphrases (20+ characters) rather than short complex passwords
Check your email at haveibeenpwned.com to see if your accounts have been breached
Change passwords immediately if you suspect a breach or receive a suspicious alert
Avoid using personal information (birthdays, names) in passwords
Be cautious when using public computers ‚Äî use private/incognito mode and log out completely
